name: Sixplay
language: Tennis, Football, Pelote Basque, Ball-trap, Tir au pigeon
keyboard: 2 detachable controllers with dials or sliders, depending on models
coprocessor: Power on/off, Ball fast/slow, Ball angle 20?/40?, Paddle size small/large, Service manual/auto
description:
Hmm, there are still many mysteries arround this system. The case is in sheet metal so it's very heavy but indestructible. It's impossible to open because all parts have been reveted. There is only one part removable on top with clips to place the 9V batteries.

The fact that the case is made of sheet metal means that only a few of these systems were produced. Indeed, plastic cases require a special and dedicated mould which is very expensive to make. Thus, the plastic solution was only adopted when large quantities of systems were produced.

All texts are in french. There is a little led that indicates whether the system is on or off. The two paddles are also in sheet metal. The problem is that we don't really know the brand of this system as there is only one name written on it - Sixplay.

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE WATCHES!</strong></font><br><blockquote>While manufacturing and selling calculators in 1977, Commodore sold wristwatches.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chuck Guzis</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the time of this advert (September 1980), Heathkit introduced a music synthetiser board, a speech lab, a color graphic board, a color monitor and Microsoft BASIC and FORTRAN languages. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert shows: <br><br> - the <b>WH89</b> computer ($2295)<br> - the <b>WH11A</b> 16-bit computer, DEC PDP 11/03 compatible ($1895)<br> - the <b>WH19</b> video terminal ($995)<br> - the <b>WH26</b> dual floppy disc system ($2595)<br> - the <b>WH14</b> serial printer ($895)<br><br>  To note: in 1979, the company name was <b>Heath Schlumberger data systems.</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the power of words depends on the way you use them"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JULY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil has all talents"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... One of the results is our new identity and our new product: the Intersystems DPS-1. An IEEE S-100 compatible mainframe with features that live up to its look. <i>Dependable</i> operation to 4 Mhz. Twenty-card capacity, a modular power supply. And something no one else has: built-in break points to give you a faster, more powerful tool for testing software as well as hardware...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH POSTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Poster in a 1982 english computer show.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Orion Young for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD (JULY, 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Eric Buczynski for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert dédicated to Polymorphic BASIC language features and to a new version of the system named System 0.<br><br> The <b>System 0</b> was intended for the users who already have a S-100 Bus based system and wanted to transform it into a Poly 88 system. It consisted of the central processor card with ROM monitor, the video card and the cassette interface, all in kit form. Price: $525 </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"MO5. Adventure built-in"<br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Northstar also designed cards for S100 Bus. These cards were used in the Horizon and were also available separately for competing systems.<br> Cards on the photo are:<br> - 16 KB RAM board ($459 assembled)<br> - Micro Disk System (card & interface) to connect Shugart FDD ($799)<br> - Z80A processor board ($259 without EPROM option, $330 with)<br> - Hardware floating point card ($359).  </blockquote>
